If it weren't for the repeated experience, your symptoms suggest poisoning rather than allergy.  Mussels (all kinds) are very perishable.  They must be properly stored and cooked at once.  From my experience of a lifetimes of harvesting my own mussels, I'd say you ate decayed mussel protein.  But I'd stay away from them.  Not worth the risk.

If you were allergic to them, you would get a rash, or maybe a throat too swollen to breathe.  I can't be sure what causes your intolerance of them, but I remember well being told that there are some months of the year when it is imprudent to eat them because they will make you sick.   Of hand, I do not remember which months, but you can probably find out on the internet!
This sounds more like food poisoning to me rather than an allergy, but I am no medical authority.

That seems like the tidiest explanation for her left optic neuropathy. In other words, the pituitary microadenoma has nothing to do directly with her left optic neuropathy. The bony changes caused by early acromegaly (which is due to the adenoma) preferentially narrowed the left optic canal--through which the left optic nerve passes--and consequently squeezed it. And these bony changes had not sufficiently affected the right optic canal (or other cranial nerve foramina). I guess it's either that or pseudopapilledema (unless her pituitary adenoma wasn't as tiny as billed). But it'd be really nice to get an official answer or best guess.

Although she's somewhat young (were we ever given her age?), her glaucoma may just be idiopathic. I agree that the history of HSV2 meningoencephalitis is probably unrelated and represents an unfortunate, sporadic infection.

But overall, this case wasn't fairly presented (Dr. Lesser gets to look at her hands and we don't??), and it was even less well explained. A better and fairer way to have presented this case--which would have also preserved the patient's identity--would have been to show a picture of the woman's hands, while conveying the information somewhere in the write-up that she's married (but not overemphasizing the fact). Then laypersons could have recognized the absence of a wedding band and asked themselves Why? The case would have been much more Sherlockian and educational, IMO.

And the point is that Dr. Lesser's curiosity was tweaked by a "soft" clinical finding, leading to further questioning and then diagnostic bloodwork/imaging. Plus you're assuming that images of her extremities would have added any additional clues in someone with pretty early signs of acromegaly.

Interesting case in that she had supposedly normal visual fields - but was seen by a neuro-opthalmologist, a subspecialty that sees a fair amount of patients with acromegaly. Without a look at the extremities I really feel that this was impossible to solve with the information given.

I agree with my colleagues that there are some unsatisfying aspects of this case.

This patient has optic disc edema with a flame hemorrhage or two. But there is no report of visual acuity, color vision, or presence of an afferent pupillary defect. I'm certain these were tested by both eye doctors.

There are no visual fields - and I suspect that they were not truly "normal" but instead either show a altitudinal defect or at least depression in foveal sensitivity. Fields help distinguish whether this is truly a unilateral process or a chiasmal syndrome. I suspect that the patient does have diabetic papillitis, but not enough information is given to rule out other conditions. It would be nice to know if the disc edema was thought due to this (which is what I think) or due to compression through the optic canal from the acromegaly - this is a slow process and often presents as unilateral optic atrophy, not edema. Pituitary lesions need to be quite large to impinge on the optic chiasm or optic nerves, typically at least 10mm in size, and this "very small" lesion would not cause disc edema.

This patient's past history would've bought her an MRI with contrast to rule out demyelinating conditions anyway (which presumably would've shown the pituitary lesion) given that she had an ocular motility disturbance (which could have been an internuclear ophthalmoplegia) and urinary problems.

I'm not disagreeing with the diagnosis, just the order in which things were presented.
